Beautiful game, but short (about 3-4 hours). Had one scene that actually scared me. Saves only at certain checkpoints, which is highly annoying! Buy it when it's on sale.  So now to compare it a bit to Dear Esther, my de facto standard for good 'walking simulators'. Which is better at what areas? Graphics -> Ethan Carter; this game is astonishingly gorgious at times, although the character models and animations are not as good as the landscape. All in all this might me the best looking game after GTA5 I have ever played. Music -> Dear Esther; EC has some great tunes but Jessica Curry's haunting tunes seem to be in a league of their own... I rarely experienced music that tore more at the heartstrings than Dear Esther's. Voice acting -> Dear Esther; EC's main character Paul Prospero's sounds great, but all the other characters are less convincing. 'Gameplay' -> Ethan Carter; this games actually has some puzzles and even a point at which you can *gasp* DIE! Atmosphere -> Dear Esther; Ethan Carter is beautiful, but lacks the melancholy soul Dear Esther presents. Basically Dear Esther's island is one big metaphore for your journey, while EC's woods and hills are seemingly just that: (beautiful) woods and hills. Mystery -> Dear Esther; while both games have plenty of mysterious events and settings and good stories, EC has a pretty nice wrap-up in the end where most has been explained. Dear Esther remains ambiguous even after several playthroughs, which I like more. Emotional impact -> Dear Esther; it basically wins because the overal presentation including music and writing is a more poetic experience; it thus affected me more than EC, although the ending of EC is also a really good one.  So once again: recommended, but not able to become my favourite 'walking game' after Dear Esther.
Absolutely mind-blowingly gorgeous, immersive, unsettling story-telling experience. It will stay with you for a very long time.

A beautiful journey through a gorgeously rendered landscape that hides deep myteries and epic tales. Not too short but leaves you wanting more. Reminiscent of Dear Esther on several notes, however I shall omit these similarities for the sake of avoiding spoilers. Perhaps slightly predictable on several points of plot and puzzle mechanics once you have got into it. But still manages to keep you guessing and throw something new at you right up to the end. Put simply, this isn't a game, it's an experience. Like walking through a book that you just can't put down. And It's one I hope to visit again, once the memory of the story fades and the puzzles solutions are lost to me. Highly recommended and I will personally be hoping for more from the developer in the future.

Absolutly amazing game. Both in visuals and the way it handles the story and themes. There is not that much in convensional gameplay per say, the puzzles are few and very easy and it's mostly walking in very pretty (but bleak) enviroments. But that is not a bad thing as long as you are prepared for it. This is what 'walking simulators' should try to be. It's a short game, but well worth playing. You are really missing out on something special if you don't play it.

When I first stumbled upon this game and watched the trailers, I thought this game was worth a try. Now that I have played it, I'm convinced that this is a masterpiece. It isn't action-packed, nor it is trying to challenge your abilities, it's simply trying to tell a story. And that it does well.  Once in the game, the first thing you'll definitely notice is the graphics. It's simply beautiful. Combine it with the atmospheric soundtrack, and you get yourself an experience you'll remember, feeling like you're actually a part of the world.  Now, about starting the game... You'll have to figure out how to play. There's no tutorial of any kind. The game starts, and you'll be standing on the (rail)road without any hints or quest markers. In fact, I'd say there are no quests at all. But don't blame the developers for being lazy. All of these things are intentional. The game is not about solving quest or beating a boss. It's about exploring and puzzle solving. It's about discovering the secrets of Red Creek Valley. And there  are  a few of those.  If you still don't fancy starting the game without some explanation about the game's mechanics, there's a commented gameplay video (with some light spoilers) on the game's Steam Store page that should have more than enough details to get started.  In general, the game is pretty simple. The interactions, the puzzles, the crime scenes - Nothing is too complicated. The reason behind is that the main focus is neither of these things. Instead, the emphasis is on the world and the story. This results in the game being surprisingly immersive and everything just feeling alive, despite the main character being the only living person in the vast majority of the game.  Though the amount of content, combined with the overall simplicity, has another side effect: short playtime. You can get from the intro sequence to the end credits in a few hours. Don't let that discourage you, though. Sometimes, ignoring the story and aimlessly wandering the forests of the valley can give you an experience that feels strangely satisfying. And if you want to rush through the game... Don't. It's okay for your second playthrough, but the first time is unique. Do it in a rash, and disappointment is pretty much guaranteed. Instead, take your time. Nothing's chasing you. Go in a pace that's comfortable for you. And live the game yourself.  Overall, I'd say that the Disappearance of Ethan Carter is a well-made, well thought-out game. It's interesting, chilling and fascinating at the same time. I'd recommend it to anyone who   Likes a game with a good story   Actually plays games for the story   Likes mysteries and the supernatural  I DON'T recommend the game if   You're looking for a challenge   You're looking for action   You can't handle something that has an obscure or secondary meaning  If you do decide to play the game, get ready for an experience that could potentially have a permanent emotional impact on you.   The final scene will hit you like a brick.

This is a game thats all about ambience and story. The actual gameplay is limited, but this is cleverly hidden by the quality of the gameplay it does have, the atmosphere, graphics and story telling you experience on your way through.  Its not your traditional game that tries to impress you with in game mechanics and systems, permutations and sandboxy gameplay. Its a small game, exquisitely crafted and streamlined to be good at what it needs to be and nothing more. Its not a game trying to be a jack of all, but what it does do, its a master of.  Is it a game with lots of replayability? No. Is it a game set in a massively detailed world with lots of interactive NPC's? No. Is this a game for achievement junkies and Steam badge traders? No.  There aren't many games out there like this. In an industry where so many over hyped, max budgetted games under deliver on multiple fronts, it feels to me that the developers of this game wanted to craft a story experience, and focussed on that, rather than on all the other bells and whistles larger games include, and get wrong.  Would i recommend it? Yes.

While the game was a little buggy at times, and I'm still not sure I understood the logic of the auto-save system, I thought this was a fantastic example of story telling through gaming. I hope more developers take this route to gaming in the future.
Beauuuuuutiful game!!loved it so much!! I wish it was a little bit longer.Now,im waithing for UE4 version.

Amazing game with brilliant graphics, was a ton of fun to play through. I like to think that I'm pretty good at solving puzzles myself, and have played/read Professor Layton, Sherlock Holmes, etc. for most of my life, but The Vanishing of Ethan Carter took being a detective in a game to a whole different level.  A few quick things about the game, and then you can be on your way: -This is not an action game. There is no shooting, ducking behind cover while the building you just escaped explodes, or anything like that. It's more ambient and thought-provoking, making you think about how to solve /this/ puzzle, how /this/ from earlier might've tied into /this/ part, etc. (in fairness, there is 1 grenade in the game, but you don't throw it at anyone/thing) -Takes about 6-8 hourse of gameplay to beat the main story, assuming you look up the occasional guide for when you get stuck/confused (happens more often then you might think, trust me). Probably longer than that if you don't use any guides, but I wouldn't know. -One of the puzzles involves a cursed miner who wanders around an abandoned mineshaft. This part is reminiscent of those jump-scare games that famous youtubers play and MatPat does game theories about. If you're a wimp like me and don't like that kind of thing, it's fairly easy to just sprint through most of it and, using a guide, figure out the code you need to put in at the end of the puzzle. If not, you can just go for it. Or you can just go for it either way, don't let me tell you how to live your life.  And that's pretty much all I have to say.  TL;DR, it's an ambient mystery game, has a short-medium length story-line, and has one part that's kinda creepy (though I haven't played enough of that kind of game to judge very well). Anyway it's a great game, pulls you in very effectively, is lots of fun, and even has a plot-twist or two thrown in there as a bonus. Definitely worth the money.

In a time where a game presenting itself as a 'narrative-driven experience' more than often leads to the uncomfortable premonition that you're in for a ride with the PC's version of a lethally boring and pretentious arthouse movie, The Vanishing of Ethan does all the right things to tell a story that actually keeps you thrilled until the last second.  On the surface, TVoEC plays like an interactive detective story - you find a corpse, seek for the most plausible cause of death, and collect evidence to create a theory of what happened. Slightly more unusual, the protagonist Paul Prospero has some sort of second-sight which allows him to have a flashback of the murder scene if he repositions certain objects the way they were before the murder. Together with these flashbacks, small bits of written text from Ethan himself help to advance the story.  'Advance' may not quite be the right word here, though. While there is some progress in the story, the game developers actually got the 'Mystery' part right - you quickly develop a plausible idea of what happened to Ethan and his family, but the longer you play, the more cracks this formerly so obvious truth gets. Not all things are quite as they seem.  Being a narrative-driven game, TVoEC's gameplay sadly is a bit lackluster. While the world looks gorgeous thanks to the UE4 engine and has some fantastic background music, what you actually do inside it rather repetive, with most ridddles following the same 'find object, rearrange murder flashback' path. Even those riddles differing from this pattern all are absolute no-brainers; stuff you would usually expect as a side dish in modern FPS games; so if you come into TVoEC expectig a second Myst, you will be sorely disappointed.  Why buy this game then? Quite frankly: Because the story really is that ♥♥♥♥ing good. Whenever you think you actually got behind what is going on, the game slaps you in the face with another revelation that makes your neat little theory crumble like a card house, or at least causes it to shake violently. Coupled with the amazing atmosphere it provides, this make The Vanishing of Ethan Carter one of the genuinely good 'walking simulators' out there.
Beautiful, mysterious, haunting... an absolutely perfect 'walking simulator' with light puzzle-solving and a touch of supernatural horror.
Great game. Great story.
This game was subtle, breathtaking, and almost just long enough.  In fact, my only real complaint was this game wasn't that long, the puzzles weren't that hard.  Powerful, intruiging, and beautiful.
a haunting story with beautiful art design. I wish there were more like it.
An incredible atmospheric suspense mystery that takes place in a beautifully wooded but desolate mining town

This is a pretty good experience, or at the very least, I enjoyed it. The game doesn't really ever give you an explicit tutorial on anything but keeps things simple enough that you can figure out most everything on your own pretty easily. And it doesn't teach you that you can make as much progress in the game world as you want while missing the story, but it's something you'd pick up on if you kept walking and felt like nothing was happening, because stuff is generally always happening, there is actually not a large amount of transitional time between the main 'scenes' of the game. The game looks and sounds gorgeous of course and even though the path is decisively linear, with a few fake branching paths and a few places off to the side of the main path, it's still enjoyable to explore. And the story is pretty interesting, kind of unsettling but not really 'scary'. The only real flaw in this game is the stupid divergeance into cheap jumpscare territory in one side area, where you're all but guaranteed to get jumped by the miner guy at least once. It's just, completely out of place and running around the bland cave area looking for bodies while trying to avoid this threat is just not what this game is about. I like the murder mysteries throughout the story, even if only the first one poses any real challenge whatsoever. The game is a bit short though, only about 4 hours to complete the first time and I ended up replaying through it quickly on the original version since the redux doesn't have a store page and I wanted to write a review. I wouldn't recommend it for full price, but on sale, certainly worth looking into. So yeah. Enjoyable enough game with a solid plot. Oh and it's a walking simulator where you can run, so, that's nice.

Beautiful beautiful beautiful game and story. Best environment in a game I've ever seen. The forest and all other areas are amazingly gorgeous. Textures are insanely detailed and look very realistic. Sound is incredible as well and the music is phenomenal. I may buy the OST after writing this. Solid 6 hours of gameplay minimum unless you rush through (and you really shouldn't rush through).  I found the puzzles enjoyable to figure out, and piecing together the story was nice too. Even just exploring the environment is interesting. I never got bored, and I always felt really immersed in the world.  I recommend playing on a high-end graphics card to really see everything at its full potential. Also, if you are too impatient to explore the world thoroughly to find all the visions (there is no HUD and absolutely no hand-holding) then I would recommend looking up ign's walkthrough just to make sure you complete them all.  If you enjoy taking your time to explore a lifelike, gorgeous atmosphere and a beautiful yet dark story, this is for you.   But the ending is sad as ♥♥♥♥, yo.

Lovely looking atmospheric game, but for some reason I get terrible motion sickness when playing. It's not really apparent what you need to do to progress the story and as I'm not one for spoiling a game by youtubing it I'm not entirely sure what the game mechanics are. Having said all that it's an immersive game world and I was more than happy to wander round the autumnal and slightly unsettling landscape just admiring the views. Worth getting if your a fan of the so called walking simulator genre.
Short, but definitely worth the money. Great story. One of the best indie games of 2014 for sure.

So good. It's a lovely puzzle game wrapped around an aesthetic that is both beautiful and at times creepy. It's serene but also offputting. Don't watch videos on it, or look up how-tos before digging in. Just go for it.
Definitly one of my favorite games.  Beautiful landscapes, interesting story and great atmosphere. I got that wonderful lovecraftian feeling of some creeping horror hidden in the shadows.

Great great Game!!! It looks so fantastic (even the non Redux version) and the atmosphere is also great. Some puzzles are very demanding, wich is nice. Story is nice, sometimes has a little creepy vibe.

While I was able to beat this in apparently only 3 hours, the story told in this game was more than worth the full price I paid for it. Can't wait to see more from The Astronauts!  This is well worth the Whoooaaaaaaa, dude! award and this will probably be the first VR game I play when/if I finally decide to splurge on the hardware.

This is one of those games I've been looking for for a long while. This isn't your regular 'by-the-book' detective game where the character tells you the whole story and helps you as a player solve the mystery by doing it all himself. This game knows it's being played by a person and tests you to really put your mind into the game and lose yourself as the character and explore. You do all the investigations yourself and put pieces together. I was pleasantly surprised by the amount of fun I had feeling the emotions of the game drift from 'exploration of tiny forest' to 'thriller crime drama' and swiftly to 'elderitch puzzle horror'. The soundtrack and composition definetly helped with that fact.  Aside from these pro's they don't come without cons. I see a lot of people praising the ever-loving crap out of the graphics, and mind you this has some WICKED SICK visuals like... damn. But the character models? Ugh, I nearly threw up. It SCREAMS Unreal Engine you know? Now I know what they blew the budget on I guess. I guess you could argue the save feature was a bit of a flaw? But I disagree since it's such a SHORT game. You could beat this game in four hours if you try, six tops if you're let's player level of trash at video games. Still, I would agree that buying this game at full price was not my best choice, but not the worst decision I ever made.  Tl;dr, pick it up if you're in for some Detective Spooky and the Mystery of Cthulhu's Country Home Explorer

Stunning game. The graphics are tremendous and I could not ask for more. The game starts slow but is awesome overall. You will need a pretty beefy PC, my Microsoft Surface couldn't even get 30FPS on minimum settings but my new PC can get a whopping 200! I really suggest you get this game if you love absolutley stunning sights!
Amazing experince, visuals, and story. A mashup of Myst and H.P. Lovecraft, it's a horror novel in the Unreal engine.

Such a Great Game!  Amazing Atmosphere & Graphics. Good Story & Animations.  But it was a bit to short in my opninion. The 'Open World' feeling gets lost in this storytelling.  But after all, i recommend this Game to everyone! A must Play!  9/10.
Refreshing game. Enjoyed alot.  Unfortunately....game is too short.

Simply wonderful. Worth the playthrough (though you might need the help of a walkthrough a bit to keep the frustration levels down... the next step is rarely obvious...).    Also, ♥♥♥♥ Ethan's brother. Seriously, ♥♥♥♥ him, for that final comment of his. I hope he regrets it forever.

This was excellent. A very short (4-hours for me) game but BEAUTIFUL! This and Alien: Isolation have to be the two most graphically impressive games of 2014.  As for the type of game, this is like a mix between the classic Myst (except it's an FPS) and Murder Soul Suspect.  It's fun and short with a very interesting story.  A+
Awsome game!!!

It's a game worth buying in discount (got it for 8 euro), the graphics are awesome, the game itself is better playing with a friend in my opinion the only think i didnt like was that you have to completed the time you started, cause i think that if you let it you will lose the magic of this game! I recommend this game to play with a friend!
Great little puzzle game. Quite short but draws you in and shows what the unreal engine can do.
This game has stunning graphics and fictional stories as you explore throughout this strange place. 8.5/10

This is a puzzle/exploration game where the rewards are furthering the story.  Good: Gothic , macabre and slightly off kilter atmosphere, lovely graphics, no frenetic shooting of any kind, you can play it at your own pace. Voice acting generally good.  Bad: Very short. Finished it in less than 5 hours. I have to say I don't think its worth its current price . Buy it on sale. However do buy it when the price is right.

I really suggest you get this game if you love absolutley stunning sights!
Mindblowing game. Play through all the way to the end and you wont be disappointed!

There is so much to be said about this game!  Quick Reference:  THE GOOD • Immersive and interesting story. • Good character development. • Gorgeous world with excelent graphics. • Good and fitting soundtrack. • Nice voice-acting.  THE BAD • Weird auto-save system. • The game does not hold your hand, so it's easy to miss things or to get lost in the world.  SPECIAL (These are topics that are too long to be in a quick reference. If you wanna read about them, go to the end of the review. There will be No Spoilers, I promise.) • The ending • Hours worth of game.   Throught review and commentary:  > IMMERSIVE AND INTERESTING STORY  Immersion is definetely the strongest point of this game. The graphics and the way the story is told and the lack of HUD make the immersion easy and enjoyable. With no HUD, there is nothing or almost nothing to distract you from the experience of playing. It's easy to fell in the shoes of Paul Prospero and the story is pretty good. You feel the need to find out what is happening, why it's happening and how things came to be the way they are. The game is a narrative experience, so this is, as it should be, it's strongest point.  > GOOD CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT  There is only a handful of characters in the story and you don't get to see them all that much, but you can clearly distinct each one of them by their personalities. The best of all, though, is not how the characters are, but how they are portrayed in some elements of the game. But I won't spoil it for you. You'll understand when(hopefully) you play the game and think hard enough about it. Have fun!  > GORGEOUS WORLD WITH EXCELLENT GRAPHICS  This is part of what makes the immersion so good. This is one of (if not the) most beautiful games I've ever played. I've found myself stopping to watch some landscapes. This made me thank myself for investing money in a great computer.  > GOOD AND FITTING SOUNDTRACK.  The sounds can really make you feel the game. Also part of the great immersion. THIS IS A GAME TO BE PLAYED ON HEADPHONES(or really loud speakers, if you and the people around you have no problem with it.) The music can make you feel relaxed, anxious, sad... Well, it does it's job well.  > NICE VOICE ACTING  Unique voices and acting won't allow you to mistake a character for another. The actors did a really good job on making each character distinguishable, even when you can only hear and not see them.     X WEIRD AUTO-SAVE SYSTEM  Well, you don't only have to learn the game here, you'll also want to learn how the auto-save system works. You will eventually feel like you can't leave play whenever you want. It is not a big issue, really. But it is something I thought was worth to mention.  X THE GAME DOES NOT HOLD YOUR HAND  The game itself says: 'This is a narrative experience that does not hold your hand.' This is the first thing you get to read in the whole game, even before the intro. Well, this is an open-world game with mysteries scaterred around. It is very easy to completely miss something. I got stuck two or three times. Well, it can happen. It is not an easy game.   >> CONCLUSION <<  One of the best experiences I've ever had with a game in my life. No wonder I came here to write such a detailed review. This is a very well-crafted game that is all about the experience of playing it. If I were to give you a piece of advice: Play this game in a moment people do not need you, or won't call you. As I said, this game is all about the immersion, and being interrupted breaks it, so try not to let yourself be interrupted.  That said, I believe this game is worth it's full price. And I do recomend you to buy it and hope you enjoy it as much as I did. Cheers!    ** THE ENDING  When you clear the game you will remember what I'm saying here: THERE IS MORE THAN MEETS THE EYE.  It is very easy to see what the ending looks like judge on the spot. People seem to do this frequently when there is SO MUCH MORE to it. When you clear this game, give the ending, and the whole story, a second thought, or research about it. You won't regret it. I promise.  ** HOURS WORTH OF GAME  This is not a long game on it's own. And replaying The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is just like re-reading a book. You will go through the same scenes again. Well, you might pick some pieces of the story you didn't get right the first time, but there is nothing completely new. Looking at it that way it seems like a short lived game. But again: There is more than meets the eye. Try to give things a second thought, rethink the game and you might find many hours of fun without being actually playing.
Took me 6.5 hours to finish, don't know why/how people can complain about it being a 2 hour game.  Also it's amazing

A nice short game that doesn't try to be overlong or waffle about. Excellent visuals and a strong story make this an excellent use of $20. The game also have some clever detective work, that is rare these days.  There's not too much action, but the trailer kind of makes that clear.

Initially I loved this game. It is possibly the most beautifully landscaped game I have ever played. I was mesmerised as I wandered aimlessly through the trees and rocks, and rocks and trees, and... therein was the beginning of my discontent. It is of course occasionally punctuated by the odd tram or house, but for me there is too much trudging up and down what feel like endless winding trails to the next set piece. Guys, would it have been so bad to have a walk toggle setting?   'Our focus is on atmosphere, mood, and the essential humanity of our characters.' In many ways you succeeded, as many reviews here testify, but in doing so you have perhaps made the game a little too obscure and beyond the reach of a lot of gamers. Also some missleading and inconsistent leaders. For instance, when you first start out, there are some fairly obvious indications towards clues which lead you to suppose this is a common precident, and yet later in the game with some of the more important clues, they are not evident at all so you could easy miss them. Beware also of back tracking to look for possible missing clues, as picking up objects at previous save points seems to erase your progress. The developers state that it is an 'experience, in non-linear fashion' and for the most part this is true, but you will encounter the invisible wall syndrome quite frequently. Jumping off bridges or swimming in the lake is definately a no-no, no matter how hard you try.  A labour of love without doubt, and worthy of praise, but if you lack patience, stamina and a considerable attention span, you could find yourself developing a thousand yard stare.

One of the Best games I played recently. Sotoryline: Awesome start, attractive and addictive in the beggining. However, the end is not so explanatory, leaving me feel like nothing actually happened. Like it's just a dream? Me myself can think of better ending. Graphic: Awesome, feeling like it's real, Took so many screenshots. However, the optimisation is not the best, my laptop is performinng lame in the highest definition. Music: Awesome. Fits the enviorment perfectly, Improve the atmosphere.  Although it's a rather short game but the expirience was so great. Especially the scenery and music. Recommend to anyone. Worth the money
Very short game. Good but very, very short.
Outstanding graphics.

I can't give this a raving review like others have, the writing wasn't the best, the story was just ok.  Graphics: Amazing graphics, feels like you are actually there. Probably the best graphics I've seen in a while.  Controls: These were functional, I used a 360 gamepad. I did have some glitches where I would get stuck on a rock and nothing would happen until you found exactly the right path to go. Wouldn't be a problem normally but the game saving for this game isn't the greatest so if you get stuck, you have to rewatch a mostly 'just ok' story.  Story: Meh - I've seen better. The acting was bad and the writing at times was painful - especially parts of the end (I won't spoil it for anyone).   What this game is is a great experience for $12. It was worth it just for the ability to walk around and explore. If you liked Dear Esther, then this is for you. It's a lot lot Dear Esther with the kinks worked out. It's a great game to play with a friend or two - everyone can backseat drive this one.

I don't know what I expected going into this game, but I had cold chills by the time I finished it. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is incredibly short, but a worthwhile experience that is hard to say too much about without ruining the journey in the game. Yes, it's beautiful and atmospheric, but the real beauty is in the journey that the playable character goes from the first moment until the very last. Yes, it will get weird at times, but stick with it and it will be a memorable experience for sure.
Good: Amazingly good-looking game, neat flashback mechanic, decent story & performances  Not as good: Hard to know where to go sometimes, some sucky jump-scares, ending felt a bit disappointing

This game is a masterpeice, problem is I played for over 1.5 hr and when I went back into the game nothing I had done was saved. Now I have to start all over. I'm not going to vote 'no' but be warned this issue still needs to be fixed. The game needs a SAVE BUTTON.

First of all, this game is absolutely gorgeous. I mean it. This game is breath taking. The story is also really well done in this game. The people who gave this game a poor rating really did miss the point of this game. This is not an action game, it's not an RPG game, there is no combat. It is a light puzzle mystery game. Think of it as a fully interactive movie. This game is more of an experience than a challenge (although some parts can be challenging). If you want a beautiful game with a great story with puzzle solving and exploration, this is your game. It really is something to be experienced for yourself. Highly recommended!
+ the story is beautiful, intriguing and loved the end. gameplay is pretty relaxing.  - not many play hours

I enjoyed this game overall and I'm glad I was able to experience this story. That is the long and short of how I felt about this game; not to say that it didn't have problems, but I'll get into that.   You play as a paranormal detective investigating 'The Vanishing of Ethan Carter'; hence the title. You find clues about him through solving the murder mysteries of his relatives. As a paranormal detective, you have a special skill of seeing exactly how they died, and where Ethan went, by solving each killing. As you progress through the game you find out more about the family members, and Ethan himself through papers you get from solving each mystery. Think of a Myst-lite crossed with murder investigatons... and that is more or less this game honestly, it isn't much broader than than that.   Speaking of Myst, this game is very heavy on exploration and immersion. However, the puzzle aspect of Myst is slightly lacking in here for this to be a perfect comparison to Myst. Not to say this doesn't have puzzles, there are quite a few in here, but they aren't as difficult or... as usually obscure, as they are in Myst. Which to be honest, i'm pretty happy about since I was able to get through the game without a guide. (I did use a guide for one of the achievements though).    This game is very short and sweet, and I was able to complete it in an afternoon. However, its length felt appropriate, not bloated or too short, I'd compare it to a nice desert and wine that follows a main course meal. That being said I have some 'minor' complains about it.   My main complaints about this game are are:  1. There are multiple parts where you have to ride an elevator up and down SlOWLY, ride some sort of locomotive SLOWLY, or just having to go through really slow areas. Not only multiple parts, which I can be fine with, but you potentially have to go through them multiple times. Not only that also, but elevators stay on the floor that you left them on, and then you have to wait while they SLOWLY come back up, and then having to wait while they take their time on going down. I HATE that we still have these parts in games, we have maps now for games with fast points. WE HAVE THE TECHNOLOGY TO FIX THIS. Which brings me to point-   2. There is no map in this game. Now I can hear people saying that having a map would break the experience of being fully immersed in this world. Those people might be right, but me breaking my keyboard in frustration brings me out of games faster than having a map would. That is all.  3. I experienced a couple hiccups in the framerate, my computer could be at fault, but I saw where other people were complaining about this also.  Other than that, this was overall a very good game. I'd recomend it to people who enjoy love, happiness, and puppies.

This is a fairly short game, but does exactly what it sets out to: to create an atmouspheric game that will stay with you after you finish it.  The murder puzzles are fun and the story is interesting enough to keep you going. A lovely creepy atmousphere with only one jump-scare (although I think it would be better without it).  The world looks amazing and runs fairly well even on older machines.  Certainly worth picking up on sale.
What started as a spooky sort of thrilling crime story, turned out to be the saddest game I ever played. The end left me crying and hoping that there will be more games from 'The Astronauts'

I haven't finished playing yet but this game is amazing. The scenery is beautiful, the puzzles are challenging, the whole mystery of what happened is being figured out by you with no real guide to say 'go this way, now go over here'. There are clues, but ultimately its completely up to you the player, just like if it was in real life. The way the character can tap into spirits and learn from them is fascinating, and each time you do it comes together just a little more. If you're skittish make sure to play this one during the daylight hours as there are a few occaisions where I almost needed a change of underwear from unexpected surprises. The detail in the environments and the change in music help to really show the magesty of the valley the game is set, to the scary/ominous areas, to making you feel completely alone and helpless. I can't wait to finish it so I can start again! 9.5/10
Breath-taking, beautiful environment. Interesting, well written story. Most of the voice actors are very good. The puzzles are a bit weak and easy to figure out. Short, but worth it!

I can just walk around Red Creek Valley for hours, it's the place with it own mystic beauty like being straight out of bloodthirsty tales. UE3 shows us a real grass, river with reflected sky, stones and wood with natural textures... There is no change in time during game so your companion is bright saturated sunset and a peculiar aura. The view is beautiful, the stories are extraordinary and I'm still curious - what happens then?

This game was everything I wanted it to be. Mysterious, beautiful and atmospheric. I am already eager to play it again and see if I missed something. I think I did. But to you who are reading this. Stop reading, buy the game.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is an expertly crafted experience that remained in my thoughts well after the credits finished rolling. The game doesn't do anything revolutionary, nor does it require complex problem solving, but it doesn't constrain you from experiencing the story in your own way, at your own pace.  The beautiful vistas of Red Creek Valley - as can be seen from the myriad screenshots in the game's Community Hub, each of which could pass as a desktop wallpaper - are just one aspect where the immense amount of polish put into the game can be seen. This attention to detail extends into the way puzzles and clues are presented to you as well as how tidbits of information suddenly become relevant and enrich the story. Almost every spoken line or scrap of paper carries some significance that might not dawn on the player until the very end (or a second playthrough).  By far the most impressive thing in the game for me, however, was the interplay of natural and supernatural elements and the way these are tied into the narrative. The story can seem cliché and simple at first glance, but once you revisit earlier events and reconsider their significance or the way the protagonist and the other characters react to them, multiple interpretations of Ethan Carter's story suddenly open up. What's in the past and what's in the present, whether what you see is fantasy or reality is up to the observer to decide, and based on the number of contrasting opinions in the game forums, most people have their own version of how the story supposedly goes.  Some locations in the game can evoke a sense of dread, but those annoyed by scripted jump scares can rest easy: if you're attentive, your nerves won't be unfairly tested.  The experience is a short but sweet one and the game resonated with me enough to warrant subsequent visits to the valley. I would have liked the puzzles to be more demanding and the locations to contain more objects providing further backgrund information on the characters, but even so, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter shows that interactive storytelling doesn't have to guide you down a straight path to be memorable and thought-provoking.
wonderfull. be sure to have the hardware to enjoy the stunning visuals.
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter    Positives

Let me start by saying, I torrented this game when it first came out and came back to purchase it so I could support the game developers for such a wonderful masterpiece.   This game is truly wonderful and I will never forget my experience playing it.  Pros - Stunning Graphics, the best I have seen to date, Unreal Engine is a beast - The story was wonderful, It was like playing a book. - The puzzles were enjoyable - The atmosphere of this game was so relaxing and I often found myself stopping and just taking in the view - Performance was above and beyond even on my (at the time) low end system, then again it's not really a demanding game.  Cons - None that I can think of, maybe wishing the story were longer so I could spend even more time in this wonderful game - OH NOES THERE'S NO COMBAT!! Yes, it's a narrative game, just sit back and enjoy the ride.  10/10

Very interesting game with awesome plot, soundtrack and atmosphere. It has some puzzles to solve (not really difficult, but they're quite a challenge). If i had to say something bad about this game, it would be one word: short.  Pros: - mystery atmosphere - plot - graphics - soundtrack - puzzles (i really love puzzles) - eastereggs - open world ( u can back to the place where you started )  Cons: - short (completed it in ~ 6hrs)  9/10 would throw grenade to river for sniper rifle again

OK yes the game is good, and I would recommend you to play it, however I don't think it is one of the greatest games I've ever played. I also do not recommend you read the rest of my review until you have played the game.  Spoilers below, you have been warned.  My main problems from the game stem from the inconsistent difficulty curve. Some puzzle will have you ramming your head into a brick wall for half an hour while later ones require you to only walk forward. The games lack of hand holding makes you explore every inch of the area just in case you miss something but many of the areas are simply completely empty and only serve as scenery to the next area.   I came across a bug earlier on which prevented me from solving one of the missions, I couldn't trigger the flashback for the item.  But even though I would still recommend you play it, I found the ending unsatisfying.

Super pleased with this one! Its beautiful in every single way! The landscapes are top notch, from the skies to the grass. Super relaxed gameplay and alot of psychological puzzles. This game doesnt hold your hand and give you obvious clues like many others do, it makes you think. A great story line and an all around amazing experience. I would totally recommend this to others. In my opinion, this game has a very Stephen King feel to it...but that is just me! Buy it.

Just awesome.   Ever since I played Myst back in the 90's I dreamed of a game world that would cater to my desire to explore. In fact I've played many first person shooters hoping to satiate this need for exploration but have always been left with the empty realization that the only reason the FPS I'm playing was created is to shoot everything that moves. The tragedy is that the FPS genre is defined by the fact that 'S' stands for shooter.  The Vanishing of Ethan Carter chucks that 'S' out the window and pulls you into a gorgeous first person perspective world meant to be savored. And damn is it gorgeous. Its also creepy as hell, and those 2 things blend together perfectly. The breathtaking vistas compel you to explore the other side of every hill and bend in the road, but the haunting soundtrack suggests that you just might not like what you find.  If you are like myself and craving an adventure game that transcends the point and click variety, consider giving this game a go.  p.s. TVoEC contains probably one of the coolest video game easter eggs I've ever seen.

This game is a work of art. Everything from graphics to sound effects is absolutely mesmorizing. Although a bit short it is none the less an amzing game. I found my self pulled into the game, its that atmospheric. At times i would stop and just stare at the beutiful scenery, the beutiful sun set, the crystal cleat water. Highly recommend it be played at full settings, trully a beutiful world. The story line is well writen, although again, short. Its at the most a 10 hour game. If your good with puzzles then you can finish it faster, otherwise its between 10-15 hours max. However its only 20 bucks, more then worth it in my opinion. The ending is a bit....dissapointing yet unique.   Do not buy if your looking for a gun shooting detective, this is not an action game, it is however an amazing puzzle/detective/mystery game.

A visual and narrative masterpiece. I spent the first couple of hours just roaming around trying to figure out what to do or what was going on. The inital stages of the game feel very slow. There's no intro, no map, no objectives. You are left alone in a semi open-world (essentially a village and surrounding area) trying to piece together together a series of strange events.   The user tags define this game as 'detective', 'psychological horror', and 'puzzle.' I would say that it's more of a first-person atmospheric walking narrative with some mystery elements. A few pointers if you decide to give it a go:   1) Do not use online walkthroughs until you are ready to move on to a new 'zone' (usually designated by new scenery, a new cutscene, or a change in music). While you're in a zone, explore every nook and cranny. It's a beautiful game, so explore it.  2) I only figured out around the 3-4 hr mark that I could run ('shift' key). Made my life a whole lot easier getting from point A to B.  3) Don't let the strange 'fantasy-like' cutscenes throw you off... they will all make sense in the end. 4) Play the game through in its entirety. It took me ~6 hrs from start to finish (including a quick run-through to find some achievements that I missed in the first playthrough). The ending may seem a bit confusing, but there are some awesome 'Vanishing of Ethan Carter Explained' websites out there that help make sense of it.  Picked it up on sale, and it was definitely worth the money. Really was a great experience.

This game looks beautiful, although it's too much for my out-of-the-box laptop to run properly. Lots of lag, double cursors, jerky voices even at the lowest graphics setting. Crouch command was only used once so why even put that in the game? One puzzle said use the mouse to rotate something and nothing happened. I had to google a solution of using keys. I'm not sure what the point of name calling the kid was. I found that really distasteful. I didn't fully understand the plot, but I have judged writing contests for middle school science fiction so I just chalked it up to the kid's weird imagination. These small things did not take much away from my enjoyment of the game. The true star is the scenery, and the puzzles were nicely varied. B+ game.

WOW. Expertly crafted. Scary and beautiful. Absolutely engaging all the way through. This is the kind of game you think about for days after, like a good movie. I kept thinking about what would happen next while I was at work. Brooding and atmospheric. Soooo gooood. Play it at night with headphones, and allow yourself to become immersed. Superlative.  PS: Game time on steam does not reflect actual time played.
Stunning and intriguing game.
Absolutely gorgeous game. Story is very well told. Thoroughly recommended. Only weak point is some of the voice acting is mediocre.
Very good game. Tear jerker. Play it.

On the one hand: Absolutely gorgeous and great story. On the other hand: this game doesn't hold your hand in the SLIGHTEST and the story is pretty short. One could consider it a 'wander around in an absolutely gorgeous example of what the Unreal engine is capable of until you randomly stumble on the next piece of the story'. If you don't like exploring, you'll probably play for 10 minutes and then move on. If you DO like exploring, you'll absolutely enjoy this game.

Walk around, solve some ghost bouncer crimes by looking at some ghost things. Look at some other things that are not ghost things that are also really pretty. Bang it out in a night. Good short game with a solid story ghost story tying it all together.  Made by some of the same team who made profanity-bursting creatine-pounding Bulletstorm?  Yes to all of it.

This is one of those games that ones will love and others despise. The game is just beautiful, has one of the best graphics of today, great voice acting and story. Contrary to that, you're looking at a short, 5 hour long gameplay, some may say a 'walking simulator' and a slow paced storytelling, which someone may find boring.  So if you are able to immerse yourself to the atmosphere of the astonishing scenery and enjoy the slow flow of the story, although short, I can wholeheartedly recommend the game, for discounted price.

I was intrigued by the very first words upon starting up this game - it doesn't hold your hand. It almost comes across as a challenge and it was one I was keen to take up. To begin with I made my way through the game without too much trouble. I even discovered some aspects that were apparently easy to miss the first time around. Eventually though I after spending well over an hour wandering around I began to get frustrated.   And that's the biggest problem with the game. Actually knowing that there was a puzzle in front of you.   Generally they weren't that taxing to solve once you came to that realisation. It took me playing for 2-3 hours and the use of a guide to work out that I actually hadn't completed several sections of the game - but I had no way of knowing that. In hindsight, I realise now that the very first encounters do allude to methods that need to be used further on. It was just too subtle to pick up on.  Visually the game is stunning. I found myself stopping regularly just to take in the surrounding scenery. It actually looks and feels like a living breathing world.   The music is mostly understated but suits the unfolding story perfectly.  The game isn't long. I played through the entire thing in around 5 hours but my playtime was definitely reduced by the use of a guide at certain spots. Normally I try to avoid external help as it detracts from the experience but in this case the lack of guidance within the game warranted it.  So if you're looking for something short and challenging with an interesting story to discover then I'd recommend giving this a look.
A very satisfying 3 hours.

Excellent narrative. Astounding enviroment. Solid plot. Original game mechanics. Its nice to be abl to play at your own pace and not be thrown over the edge for making a mistake (I.E can't die). Definately recommend if you like mystery/supernatural themed games.

I do not have much time on it yet but I like it, very unique approach to gameplay, was waiting for the steam controller or the Xbox one wireless controller pc usb to come out to play this on the big screen since it did not work in triple screen eyefinity but now that the redux came out it does and the graphics are great! Check out thew trailers to see if you think the gameplay looks fun to you and if it does I highly recommend this game.
This game has a fantastic story, and a interesting mechanic.
Beautiful scenery Interesting story Easy to play Nice mystery
Fantastic story game. True to its word, it doesn't hold your hand—but hold out and solve the puzzles yourself. It's worth it.
cool game, just make sure you have a super computer to run it.

'The Vanishing of Ethan Carter'... What shall I say? This game is a true masterpiece of gaming history. The graphics are brilliant, because the game is based on storytelling, not game mechanics. Just take a closer look...  Graphics: Amazing what the programmers did with the Unreal-engine. You can encounter one of the most beautiful landscapes I've EVER seen in a videogame. Maybe due to a bad graphics card (Geforce GTX 560 ti) I had some stutters while playing.  Gameplay: The gameplay is quite small. You walk, look and sometime press your left mousebutton to read something. That's it. The riddles woven into the game are not too hard, but might cause some headaches.  Story: The story is a bit weird and you will just understand it just in the end.  Short form: a boy is lost. You gotta search him. To go on you have to solve cases of murders. The end left me deeply disturbed and sad. Those who already played this game will understand.  Conclusion: An amazing game, which is sadly too short. And that is my only critic. I've beat the game in 5-6 hours. And I took some time just to stand around and look at the landscape. I strongly recommend you this game.  I wish 'The Astronauts' financial success, so they can make more amazing games. Good work guys.

Well! I'm glad I played that. The texturing was beautiful and the story kept me guessing until the very end. Then it made me sad.  I admit, I had to resort to online playthroughs in a couple of spots -- I had no idea what the game wanted me to do. But I soon got used to the rhythm of it and finished without further hints.  I'm not sure the story was quite as spectacular as the reviews indicated, but I walked away from the game still thinking through the plot. Well above average for a storytelling game.

‘The vanishing of Ethan Carter’ is an example as to why video games are art.  ‘The Vanishing of Ethan Carter’ has one of the most vibrant, beautiful and mysterious worlds that I have seen in recent games. It gives you little to no advice on what to do, leaving the new player to wander aimlessly in an open world. So take your time to explore. This game doesn’t play around when it tells you it won’t be holding your hand.  This game combines the ‘walking simulator’ experience with engaging and challenging gameplay. It also combines different types of challenges, surprising the player. though I must say the difficulty seemed to decrease nearing its climax, allowing more of a ‘flow’ in the storyline but at times it was simply a bit too easy compared to the rest of the game. It definitely focuses more on the story than gameplay.   The music in this game is absolutely stunning and a huge contribution to the atmosphere. It’s a present element but not overpowering, inviting the player to enjoy the equally enchanting scenery.   The redux version saves more frequently and eliminates a few aspectes of the game that were considered ‘immersion breaking’ (trying to be spoiler free).  Video review:         YouTube™ Video:  The Vanishing of Ethan Carter Soundtrack - Ethan's Theme
What a game, simply perfect. Even if it is a little bit too short (4-5h) it evokes emotions that often longer games don't create. Waiting for a new materpiece.

Great Graphics and World Design, interesting Story and Puzzles.  I had the game preordered, but due to the very short time it takes to finish I would say it wasn't worth the full price. Wait for a discount.  Bonus points though for giving out the Remaster to all original owners! (look at State of Decay for a lesson of how NOT to do a remaster...)

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a beautiful looking game that tells the story of Ethan Carter and the relationship with his family in a very interesting and engaging way. It's important to realise that is more an interactive visual novel than a straightforward adventure game. It has more in common with games like Dear Esther and Gone Home than Gabriel Knight and the Black Mirror series. But the inclusion of the puzzles and the way the story is told, sets it apart from these games. Compared to traditional adventure games, the game is fairly short. It should take you about six hours on a first playthrough and less than half that on a second playthrough. The replay value lies in the story and the way it's told. Once you've reached the end you'll see everything you've experienced in a new light. On a second playthrough you'll have a much better understanding of the 'real' story and pick up on dozens of subtle clues that you probably missed the first time around. Once you've finished the game it's worth to scour the forum for more information about the story of the game. There are a lot of interesting theories (some confirmed by the creators) and links to in depth interviews with the creators. These forum posts are full of spoilers so don't bother with them until you've finished the game. I'm serious, don't, you'll spoil the surprise. Besides the engrossing story I also really liked the psychic detective puzzles, seen in one of the videos above. They're unique to this game and I wish there would've been more of them.  I recognized a lot of my younger self in Ethan (though my family was much nicer and didn't get killed) and that really helped to draw me into his world and his story. So if you're also a little like Ethan Carter, and you were reading horror, detective, science fiction and fantasy books at a young age and loved to write stories yourself, you should really play this game.

Easily one of the most beautiful games I've ever played; both for its vivid environments, fascinating puzzles, and for succeeding in making the feels happen. If you like puzzles, dark and creepy themes, fantastic visuals, and challenging gameplay, this is high on my recommendations list.

Very atmospheric game with interesting muder mystery puzzles. The gameplay is simple and it feels more like an interactive story, but the suspense kept me going.   I love the fact that it offers zero HUD navigation elements for navigation, but sometimes the visual cues don't work very well to guide the player through the world.  TThe story quality rises and falls along the game but he twist at the end was worth it!
A good exploration game
Really beautiful setting, innovative puzzles, and really just a totally different exploration/detective/mystery experience. I always find myself going back as well, just for a fresh look.

Don't be fooled by my playtime, I simply didn't have an internet connection.  So, the  story  is interesting and has some  puzzles  that  USUALLY  aren't too boring or agonizing. The  graphics  are astonishing and the game runs pretty smooth. People say that the story is very well made.... but I cannot say 'YES'; the dialogues aren't very realistic... too storyteller styled and exagerated at some points. ('Look grandpa! <activates the mecanism to [...]> So the sleeper was [...]! ...' And so it continues in a way so the player really has to be very... slowminded to not understand what is going on)  There's something in my way of experiencing the full beauty of this game: I am trapped in a puzzle where I have to hide from a malevolent being and seek corpses to open a portal.... I allways miss 1!! That's very agonizing. I would still recommend the game because it's nice enough to buy and waste some time (once in a while) completing the game.  Little tip: When you hear a strange name that isn't directly related to Nathan's family, note it down!

Interesting game with beautiful graphics. But it's too hard to solve the puzzles. I don't see how anyone could accomplish the 14 achievements without access to the walkthroughs/strategy guides. For example, how else would I know that I need to find FIVE traps in the forest in the very first scene? After I find two, or three, or four traps, there's nothing to tell me that I should keep looking for another one.

FIRST OFF! I would like to give the devs two thumbs up for this masterpiece!!!  THIS STORY IS WHATEVER THE PLAYER WANTS TO MAKE OF IT. The game is beautiful in terms of aesthetics and its story. Personally, I was initially on the fence as to what should be expected from this title as it is not my usual genre (usually having a preference for platformers and shooters) and some negative feedback with regards to the game ending and 'game save' issues had me worried. With regards to the 'save point' issues I read about, I EXPERIENCED NONE. As for the story, if you choose to take the story events at surface value you may have a negative experience, but I implore you to search the story for the deepest implications it could have and hopefully this work will leave you content at the very least.   Pros: + Amazing Graphical Style + Beautiful Soundtrack + In-depth Story + Decent/Good Voice-acting + Intuitive Game Mechanics + Puzzle Quality; Hard enough usually to make you think for a second but generally not hard enough to cause frustration + Environmental Exploration Opportunities  Cons: - Skipping over puzzle locations can lead to the need for back-tracking, which some may find frustrating - Dialogue sometimes cuts short if you leave from a 'scene' area too quickly (rare occurrence) - Environmental Audio Transitions; on occassion environmental sound transitions are too abrupt (an example, would be standing in a doorway and hearing no sound from a nearby waterfall and then hearing it roar the moment you exit the doorway) - Lack of combat for those that appeals to - Somewhat short with around 5 hours of playtime  ***PURCHASING/AVOIDING POINTS***  ***ABSOLUTE must-buy if looking for a quality game with a reasonable price-tag*** ***AVOID if walking through the environment to find areas of interest bores you as you will have to do this some***  I absolutely recommend this game and to those who play it, enjoy the ride.
Worth Every Penny!
cool game, just make sure you have a super computer to run it.

Is it good? Well it's half four in the morning and I've just finished playing the game end to end, despite only getting around 13fps (original, not even the redux). Engaging and beautiful, the story drags you along and one of the puzzles in particular (portals puzzle) was brilliant.
This game is dope af.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is an adventure game developed by The Astronauts that puts the player in the shoes of detective Paul Prospero as he visits the American town of Red Creek Valley to find clues about the disappearece of the titular Ethan Carter boy, only to find the town long abandoned and filled with mysterious murder cases.  The videogames takes place in a huge map the player can roam freely. In this map there are several points of interest that clue the player in a murder that was committed on the location: your objective each time is to examine the surrounding area for clue and put all the pieces together or simply explore the place, solve a puzzle of some sort and uncover a tale left by Ethan behind. As the developers inform you on starting the game, no one is holding your hands here, so you can 'solve' the various 'puzzles' in any order you wish or being one just to drop it and come back later. Be mind however than in order to 'complete' the Vanishing of Ethan Carter you must clear all the challenges and reach the final location of the game.  The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a catchy adventure/puzzle game spotting gorgeous environment, so you may enjoy it even if you aren't that interested in these kinds of games

Such a Great Game!  Amazing Atmosphere & Graphics. Good Story & Animations.  But it was a bit to short in my opninion. The 'Open World' feeling gets lost in this storytelling.  But after all, i recommend this Game to everyone! A must Play!  9/10.

I cannot describe in words how outstanding this game is; seriously do not hesitate to buy this game! It is so beautiful and artfully crafted; it gives me chills every time I play it because I'm never quite sure what is around the corner yet there is not a single bit of violence you're involved in.

Very beautiful, atmospheric, and cerebral game. While some classify it as a 'horror' its more of a slow-burning ghost story - there's much more exploring and story build-up than action or 'gotcha' scares. Great game for anyone looking for something new in the indie genre that takes a lot of time and patience to get through.

If I hadn't played Divinity, this game would've been GOTY 2014 for me. This is a great story. You won't fight anything, and in that regard, maybe you'd be better off watching a YouTube playthrough. Still fantastic, though.

If your graphics card can handle the beautiful and extremely highly detailed imagery that this title brings, then you really should give this one a try, it takes a few (5-6) hours to complete if not playing in a rush, and with a few parts which take a couple of cracks to get through the puzzles, this is a wonderful Lovecroftian adventure.   Plus side: - The graphics, eac surface and rock is unique, each view is not some rehash of any other view in the game. The game world is entirely believeable.  - The puzzles, they're good puzzles and they a guide for you as they're completed. - The story telling aspect of the title is excellent.  - Excellent musical and sound effect accompanyments.   Minus side: - Not enough use of the 'sense' ability in puzzle solving, in my opinion. - Very high graphic card requirements. - Original version game save points are disappointingly far between each other  Even purchasing this game now, there is a free REDUX version given out by the creators for an even richer visual experience. I played the redux version (NOTE: 6+ hours on redux, only 2 on this original version), the graphical requirements of the standard version are lower.   This game does not hold your hand. Recommended.
I had to lower the graphics settings because the game looks so good that i was taking screenshots literally every 30 seconds.
This game taught me I would make a terrible Batman. Regardless, it's a great game.

Updated: 02 Jul, 2016 @ 01:37am  Played the game again and had fun again. Free, upgraded 'Redux' also made me cange my review.  ##################################################  Updated: 24 Dec, 2014 @ 12:30am  Okay, actually I do not write too much, so here's the long story short. Positive: +graphics (almost all parts look amazing) +sound & music +gameplay (little too much walking if you forgot to solve a puzzle) +athmosphere (grahpics, sound and music are absolutely coherent)  Average: #story (could be longer anre more focused on murder/horror and less fantasy stuff)  Negative: -character graphics (they look like 2008) -the puzzles are very few and way too easy to solve -the environment is quite dead (no animals, not even birds) -always the same daytime and weather (excpet for the spirit mode)  I still enjoyed the game on the first time playing it. But now I started playing a second time and I just can't... The more I think about it, the less I think I liked it. I would not recommend this game to average gamers.

Very beautiful and interesting game. If you are tired of games that require you to the reaction, a lot of brains and endless grinding sessions, this game where you can take a break from this. In this game you need from just care. You can not play and aimlessly roam the world of the game, while enjoying the beautiful scenery and enjoying elegant music. The game does not lead you to the handle on the story, but you can be sure that this is not a very complicated puzzle.  Mystery and detective, what could be better?  My score: 8.8/10

Looking through quite a few reviews and watching the videos, I decided I wanted to try this game. With the cool concepts and off the beaten path gameplay I figured this would be a joy to play. It certainly is- great visuals, music, puzzles and mystery. That being said, it seemed to end abruptly. Before I knew it, Game Over for Paul Prospero. I was hoping for a bit more than ~3 hours of gameplay (I scoured the map while running the whole time I played). It almost felt like a teaser if you are expecting closer to the story length of most games these days.  I bought this game on a sale for less than $7. That being said, worth the price of going to a matinee and I would recommend it. It certainly keeps you engaged and is extremely well done. Buying full price at $20 is a little steep, so watch out for any sales if possible.

Lovely looking atmospheric game, but for some reason I get terrible motion sickness when playing. It's not really apparent what you need to do to progress the story and as I'm not one for spoiling a game by youtubing it I'm not entirely sure what the game mechanics are. Having said all that it's an immersive game world and I was more than happy to wander round the autumnal and slightly unsettling landscape just admiring the views. Worth getting if your a fan of the so called walking simulator genre.

This is a pretty good experience, or at the very least, I enjoyed it. The game doesn't really ever give you an explicit tutorial on anything but keeps things simple enough that you can figure out most everything on your own pretty easily. And it doesn't teach you that you can make as much progress in the game world as you want while missing the story, but it's something you'd pick up on if you kept walking and felt like nothing was happening, because stuff is generally always happening, there is actually not a large amount of transitional time between the main 'scenes' of the game. The game looks and sounds gorgeous of course and even though the path is decisively linear, with a few fake branching paths and a few places off to the side of the main path, it's still enjoyable to explore. And the story is pretty interesting, kind of unsettling but not really 'scary'. The only real flaw in this game is the stupid divergeance into cheap jumpscare territory in one side area, where you're all but guaranteed to get jumped by the miner guy at least once. It's just, completely out of place and running around the bland cave area looking for bodies while trying to avoid this threat is just not what this game is about. I like the murder mysteries throughout the story, even if only the first one poses any real challenge whatsoever. The game is a bit short though, only about 4 hours to complete the first time and I ended up replaying through it quickly on the original version since the redux doesn't have a store page and I wanted to write a review. I wouldn't recommend it for full price, but on sale, certainly worth looking into. So yeah. Enjoyable enough game with a solid plot. Oh and it's a walking simulator where you can run, so, that's nice.
I nominated this for the 'WHOOOAAAAAAA, DUDE!' AWARD.
Most beautiful and believable game yet.

I've originally written a negative review, here are my reasons for it:  - It's definitely overhyped. I'd hesitate to call it a masterpiece. Prior to bying it I read the reviews and was expecting to be blown away with it's flawless craftsmanship. Go in with lowered expectations and you will have a good time.   - It's a pretty short game, and the fact that it's actually good will leave you wanting a lot more.  Reasons why I changed my mind:  - I've since played others of this genre and realized that this is actually one of the best of it's kind.  - It goes on sale all the time and if you buy it at a discount it is absolutely worth it. The only reason I'd say it's not at full price is because of it's length.  ORIGINAL:  TL;DR: An enjoyable game, but is neither worth $20 or the praise that it receives.   Pros: The visuals and the audio are beautiful and convey a haunting and immersive experience, very atmospheric.   It is a good story and it is easy to care for the characters.   Cons: The game is very short, the world is very small. If you can get it on sale go for it, but it does not measure up to other other games of the genre and price on Steam.  The puzzles are very simple and not all that interesting, which does not help the game last any longer.  The save problem is not as bad as other reviews make it seem. There isn't really any significant progress lost if you log out between check points, nothing that you can't recreate instantly once you know what you are doing.

This game is something special, it's more than your typical game. I really enjoyed the 2~3 hours of gameplay and i never felt like the game was 'stretched' in any way. It creates an atmosphere that is truly unique. The whole game feels natural and truly immersive. I would definetly recommend this game to anyone who likes mystery and murder, while also enjoying amazing game design and storytelling.

I really enjoy old school adventure games, with their puzzle solving aspects, and this definitely has that. There are lots of exploring bits that if you don't look carefully, you won't find. It also isn't hand-holdy at all, which is a nice change from modern point and click style adventures. However, one of the puzzles is a jump-scare style which I wasn't anticipating, and kind of removed the fun exploration part for me, as I am a big-time wuss.
This is a definite must-play for anyone into story-driven games. Great story, immersive, very fun.
This game is beautiful in every way. Its abstract stroy telling is very unique.
'Best looking storyteller ever.. ends with you wondering about life itself. Cant wait for more from The Astronauts' - Cole Gilmore - Como_Esbestos

One of the most beautiful and haunting games I've played. While mostly being a walking simulator with a couple of puzzles mixed for good measures. This game captures the uneasy feeling of being in an abandoned mining town in the middle of nowhere, without the use of cheap scare mechanics. A must play game in my opinion that will only cost you 2-3 hours of your life.
Beautiful game, short but worth the play through!
This game is beautiful in every way. Its abstract stroy telling is very unique.

I did not expect too much for this game but after playing it for a little bit I got into it quicky I really like the way it tells the story and the story itself was very well done if you like 3D walking stroy game this one you should try it... but you are not into story base game this is not for you
Great game!! the atmosphere it sets drag you into the story and keep you engaged even when it gets frustrating.
I've played only the redux version and it is a little masterpiece.

I will make this very simple. The save system cripples this game.  The game is absolutely stunning to look at and a joy to walk around in and play.   I don't care about the price, because even if it's only 5 hours or so the atmosphere is so well done and it's so pretty to look at that I feel it's worth more than $5 or $10.  The deal breaker is the save system where you can play for 30 minutes or even a whole hour or more... and you need to go out or go to sleep... and you return to the game and nothing you've done has saved. I can't tell you how frustrating it is to 1) have no idea when something has saved, and 2) Not be able to save when I need to take a break.  Why? What reason would they have for making you lose all your hard earned progress pretty much every time you quit? And make no mistake, it will happen pretty much every time you quit because you never have any idea when the game is saving or where.  Were it not for that one thing I would whole heartedly, 100% recommend this game... but the save system really, really sucks!

Very overhyped. Recommended as 'art', but it's an interactive story, not a game  I've got to admire the makers for giving us a distinct and beautiful open world game with a melancholic and eerie atmosphere throughout. It's like wandering around a weird abandoned wilderness that lies somewhere between a Stephen King novel and Myst. The graphics and music can't be faulted.  However, as much as it has shown great potential in the likes of Flower and Shadow of Colossus, this to me is a sign that this indie trend of 'games = art' is getting a little tired, at the expense of producing a game that actually has gameplay. So you get a fanbase easy to please by a world with a nice setting atmosphere and graphics regardless of what the story and gameplay are like.  I had my eyes on this since it was released, and really wanted to like it, as I heard 'Lovecraftian point and click adventure' and thought 'well there still aren't enough of those'. saw the trailer and screenshots and was convinced.  Unfortunately though this barely functions as a point and click game. Sure the reviews clearly say already this is 'short and sweet', some estimating the game length at 4 or 5 hours. Mine has been logged at around 6 I think, but I spent so much time backtracking I could have done it in half the time. More on this issue I had later. Reviews online have also referred to its 'restrained story'. No kidding, there barely is one, and I found the ending disappointingly anticlimactic in terms of gameplay and cryptic and somewhat cliched in terms of the story resolution, also the 'Lovecraftian' setting was hugely overstated. It works more as a Stephen King psychological horror than anything else. .  Regarding the point and click functions, I found every puzzle laughably easy once you work out the logic behind the game, which takes a while, because perhaps not unusual for a point and click, it does basically throw you into an open-world wilderness at the start and leave you to figure out how the basics of the game work as you go along. So as stated I spent half the game backtracking and doing bits and bobs of puzzles in a weird order until I figured out how the process of puzzle solving works in this game. Once you do get it it's exactly the same thing every time, doesn't get any harder, if anything with the last few it gets easier. A learning curve doesn't exist in this game.  This game is a pleasant experience and journey, and the basic story surrounding the family is rather moving, but don't expect much of a game or a challenge out of it, and I frankly wouldn't bother unless it's knocked down to under £10 in a steam sale. The whole atmospheric Lovecraftian point and click has been done far better before in my opinion in the Darkness Within games, which had more puzzles, more gameplay and a darker atmosphere to them, despite presumably having a considerably smaller budget and less slick graphics.  P.S. As stated by reviews online and on steam, the autosave system does indeed leave a lot to be desired

Listen, if you want to experience a beautiful forest, get in a car and drive for twenty minutes. There's usually one nearby. If you want to experience a beautiful forest on your monitor, take a few digital pictures while you're in the real thing, then look at them at home. Don't waste your time with this game.  Hackneyed Lovecraftian plot, awful writing and even worse voice acting. This game is frankly terrible. Yes, it looks nice, but so what? Avoid.

To put it simply, It is a beautiful looking game, and was quite enjoyable to play. However under 10 hours for total completion for $20.00 is absurd, $5-10 is all this is worth (maybe), there is no replay value at all, once you are done, that is it. Give it a go when it's on a special..

First thing, the game looks awesome!  When I entered it, I was very happy about the freedom you have. No one tells you where to go or what to do. But that's not entirely true as I found out while playing. On a lot of occasions you will face invisible walls that force you to follow a certain path. And that's what bugged me the most. In the beginning you're told, that the game won't hold your hand and that it's about exploring. But in fact the way you go through the game is pretty well defined. That is in some way understandable because there have to boundaries where the games world ends. But creating those by invisible walls feels extremely cheap and uninspired...
I like what they tried to do with the game, it looked great. But in de end it was a walking simulator, no replay value since you cant actually make any choises.

Being a fan of games like Dear Ester, Gone Home, and the likes, I had very high hopes for this game. Alas my disappointment was big. Very.  After several annoying bugs I finally got the game to work and was set for a few hours. The atmosphere Red Creek Valley sets is perfect. It looks beautiful, it sounds perfect and your goals and how to find them become clear soon enough.  But then the flaws begin to trickle through. Red Creek Valley is big. Too big. All too soon you find yourself searching for a needle in a haystack. Oh, did you miss that? Well, better go back or you won't be able to finish the game!  To me, that's not the game's disclaimer 'not holding your hand', that's developers being to lazy to create something that makes sense as a whole. It's like a world with very few random interactive spots thrown around, to not distract you too much from their beautiful graphics simulator.  And when you finally find something to keep you from falling asleep during those long hikes, it's equally boring and unintuitive. Puzzles, if you can call them that, are way to easy and are a mere distraction. And when you are backtracking a story you find yourself running around looking for items like a fool, in places these items would never be. Tedious.  As far as the story itself, there are parts that are very creative, and made me regain my interests, and then there are parts that made me go: 'Oh dear.' Especially the ending, which, to be honest, turned an OK story into a pretty silly one.  All in all, I would only recommend this game if you could get it in a sale, and want to run around in beautiful Red Creek Valley. Don't bother about the story, though, you'll just get annoyed.
