Kind of a  'Blair Witch Project'  thing. Atmosphere, horror, a few jump scares. Very beautiful world (Unreal Engine 4) with nothing to do in it.  Shockingly low on content and gameplay elements.  Very short too. Background story is a crude horror/mystery tale about a family possessed by a ghost and killing each other, largely told through a narrator and letters strewn across the game world (lame excuse for lacking real content and interactivity).  Your job is to reconstruct who killed who, and this is how it goes:  You run around and come across typical adventure items (a lamp, an axe, a dead body, etc.), but you cannot interact or do anything with them. All you have to do is  find  all items in a certain area, which automatically prompts a flashback scene with 5 story elements and you have to guess the sequence of events, like this: (1) he picked up the axe, (2) he talked to his brother, (3) he went over to the chapel, (4) he killed his uncle, (5) he talked to his mother. That's it. Then you head to the next area, find all its items, flashback pops up..... You do this guess-the-sequence thing for the fate of each family member. That's all there is, basically.     'This game doesn't hold your hand.'    What game? At best, this is a 3D tech demo for UE, not a game. Shame on the Polish developers for charging money for a demo.

This is pass number #1 of my review of 'The Vanishing of Ethan Carter'. I'm going to break this up into a few different categories.  Graphics: Some of the best I've seen. Beautiful environments that seem close to photo realistic. Truly remarkable. HOWEVER this seems to be a pretty poorly optimized game. I run the game at a constant 60 FPS however I get an almost unbearable 'micro-stutter'. I have went through hours of forums and tried several different methods; editing the ini, turning on / off smoothing etc. Nothing seems to help. Sadly I feel like this is unacceptable. When you buy a game you shouldn't have to spend hours editing .ini files trying to make it work.  Sound: Wonderful melodic soundtrack is married with well done (if a little underutilized) voice work. Can't complain on this end at all! Well done.  Story: I haven't beaten the game yet (mostly because I have spent so much time trying to make it work); however the story is very intriguing and reminiscent of a Lovecraftian tale! Certainly keeps the momentum going. Can't wait to continue.  Overall thoughts: I'm currently giving this game a thumbs down. Not because I don't think this game isn't great; it certainly is; potentially could go down as one of my favorites. However the amount issues are insane! Launcher didn't work, controller didn't work, constant stutter and audio locked a low volume. All of these issues are fixable (except for stutter as far as I'm concerned) however you have to waste WAY to much time making this work. It's a bummer these issues bring down such a remarkable game. I'll edit this review once I finish the title.

This game is a playable mystery movie. It is not about action, it is about watching the plot unfold as you solve puzzles. Your character has very limited abilities in the 'movie' - you can walk/run, view things, interact with things, and crouch. Everything is in first-person view. There is no real 'action' - you won't be shooting at things, or ducking, or anything like that. You will be moving from puzzle to puzzle in order to advance the plot.  Graphics are very pretty (Unreal engine), and when everything is turned up to max it can cause even a beefy system to jitter every now and then. Sound consists or eerie music and environmental sounds, all of which are good.  I find it hard to say if the game is good or bad... The very first words you see upon running the game tell you flat out that the game does not hold your hand. Simple puzzles are just that, but more advanced puzzles are not self-evident. If you like puzzle games, you will probably like this game. If you like playable movie games, you may like this game.  I like puzzle games (e.g., Portal, Portal 2, Limbo, etc.). I don't have much experience with playable movies, although the PlayStation Drake's series feel that way. This game just hasn't drawn me in.   One annoying feature of the game is savegames. The game only does saves at certain checkpoints, and those checkpoints, from what I can tell, are at the beginning of each puzzle. Some puzzles take a while to complete, so if you do 80% and then need to close the game, when you load the game up you lose all your progress. I really hate that.  As a result of all this, I won't give the game a global recommendation. If you like puzzle games and playable movie games, you may like this game. I would keep a walkthrough handy if I were you...  Rating: 3/5

I played the Redux version of this game, which apparently has nicer graphics, for 94 minutes. However, as of this moment, Steam will not let me review that version, because apparently it shares the same store page as the normal version...and the normal version won't detect the playtime of the Redux version, so I had to manually load the normal version, keep it open for a few minutes, then close it to be able to review the Redux. So with that out of the way, here we go...  This is a very pretty game, both visually, and its sounds. If that and rare bits of story popping in on occasion are enough to make you love a game, then this might be for you. However, if you want anything other than visuals, sounds, and some story, this game may very well leave you terribly unfulfilled, and/or bored. I had to push myself to play as long as I did. I needed something to interest me, and I could not find it, even when something the game presented as exciting occurred. In fact, I got bored with the 'exciting' thing and looked away in the game to check something else out and missed a little bit of the scripted event as a result. If the stuff this game presents as exciting can't even keep me interested, its primary gameplay (wandering around and looking at stuff) which takes up the majority of the gameplay time, has no hope of entertaining me.  One might say I hate 'walking simulators,' but I liked SOMA, and it's almost a walking simulator, but it unfortunately features horror elements. Stuff trying to kill you in that game was my least favorite part of it, and I would have found the game to be better if none of that was in the game, with just the walking around, the dialog, and maybe a handful of puzzles at most. The philosophical aspects and world in that game were cool, and it's incredibly memorable. However, the parts that were unlike a walking simulator were the least enjoyable parts, and I would prefer the game without them, even if that meant no puzzles and a little more dialog, etc.

I was really excited to play this game, investigating a paranormal mystery in a beautiful environment, it sounded so promising.  My initial reaction was, “wow this looks great.” That was until I started moving then my reaction changed to, “oh god what is wrong with my eyes?” The motion blur on this game is horrific, it quite accurately recreates the way you eyes feel when you are so tired that you can no longer focus properly. This quite quickly gave me a headache but fortunately you can turn off motion blur and then you can actually enjoy the gorgeous scenery.  Now getting to the actual game, it is like someone played Dear Ester and thought we should make a game like that but add some more user interaction like some puzzles or something. This in itself is an excellent idea and could have resulted in a great game but this is not it. Where Dear Ester subtly guides you along a fairly linear path and advances the story, this game just give you an expansive environment and makes you go and find tiny objects hidden about the place. You spend ages scouring the forest getting more frustrated, that is if you don't miss the puzzle entirely. This scenario needs a team of scene of crime officers to systematically search the area not a nut job paranormal investigator erratically running about the forest tampering with crime scenes. As you do manage to complete the puzzles it progresses the uninspiring story. Then just when I lost all interest in the story it surprisingly managed to culminate with a nice conclusion.  So yes this is beautiful and the ending is quite good but in my opinion rest of the game make it not worth bothering with.
as of right now i dont like the game

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is visually beautiful.  The story is well done, but surprisingly short. Most of the time played was spent running around looking for text I could interact with, which is sparse. The player cannot interact with the world in any way save for in very specific locations in a very large area. Want to look at that book? Nope. Open that  door? Nope. There is a reason for this, but it detracts from the game play. There wasn't enough meat in the story, for me, to support the end and the brevity of the story. Nor was there enough character connection for me to care very much about the characters. The end I got was interesting, but it could have been so much more. And for 20 buckaroos, it should have been.  I recommend this game for its visual beauty and sound. Good for a sale. Otherwise, no.

Went into this knowing absolutely nothing about it, just taking a risk and playing on a whim.  To be honest. I wouldn't recommend this as a 'game' as such but it does a great job as a 'tech demo' or promo reel for the art department. Undeniably impressive to look at it's like walking through digitized picture postcards.  I'm a little less enthused by the story, plot, atmosphere and immersion overall though. It's like starting a Steven King novel two chapters from the end. You know, when they go all paranormal and the suspense, buildup and interest gets dumped out in favour of his tradmark unreal guff towards the end. Unfortunately we start the story of Ethan Carter about there. The cliches run through the brief experience like the river that runs through the settlement you find yourself in. The area of exploration is relatively small which actually turns out to be a blessing in disguise.   Without any real explanation as to how the mechanics work as it's a 'narrative experience that doesn't hold your hand' (or, 'we're pretentious and if you don't get how this works first time you're an idiot'), you're left to figure things out for yourself. This would be fine in itself if the 'game' didn't then penalise you with drudgery in the form of hiking back through the same scenes for missing things you weren't aware you were looking for in the first place (this is sprung on you very close to the end). Once you realise these picture postcards you're walking through are essentially sterile and somewhat stuck in time, backtracking becomes less than appealing.  It's a product that thinks it is a lot cleverer than it actually is. Stripped of the oh-so pretty scenery and some nice musical cues it would be a bargain bin knockoff supernatural paperback.  A lot of work has definitely gone into this and it shows, but unfortunately it relies on its looks a little too heavily and once you scratch that expertly rendered artistic veneer, there's little of substance beneath.   Can't really recommend it which is a shame as it's certainly worth a look, but really only a 'look' - maybe watch it over someones shoulder instead, or read a Steven King novel whilst using a postcard of New England as a bookmark.

So it's sad but the main reason I bought this game is because it was pretty. And the scenery is really nice to look at... I had to turn off the motion blur but with everything else on high it just looks so vivid and alive. But unfortunately graphics aren't the only thing you need in a game, and the gameplay in this is rather weak. It basically boils down to a handful of puzzles to solve, none of which are that difficult. And after you solve all the puzzles and beat the game there's really no replay value unless you want to take nice, quiet walks in the woods. So I just stumbled through the game in a little over 4 hours, got all the 'side stories' and even though I had fun I really can't recommend the game at the current price tag of $19.99. So... hold off on this game until it's at least 50% off or more. It's fun, and it's pretty, but it's just way too short for the price.
